snippet: Under pressure from the United States, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, rescinded Iran’s invitation to the meeting a day after he offered it.
abstract: American and other Western diplomats salvage long-awaited peace conference on Syria by pressing United Nations Secretary Gen Ban Ki-moon to rescind his invitation to Iran; possible presence of Iranians had infuriated Syrian opposition leaders, who said they would not attend; although the summit is back on track, negotiations are expected to be difficult and long.

byline.original: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANNE BARNARD
byline.contributor: Michael R. Gordon reported from Washington, and Anne Barnard from Beirut, Lebanon, and Geneva. Reporting was contributed by Somini Sengupta from the United Nations, Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul, Hwaida Saad from Beirut, and Alan Cowell from London.

lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the United States, Ban Ki-moon, the United Nations secretary general, rescinded Iran’s invitation to the meeting a day after he offered it.

headline.main: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin, but Iran Is Not Invited
headline.print_headline: Talks Over Syria Are Set to Begin; Iran Not Invited

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
